description: whatis - display one-line manual page descriptions

global_flags.description: this  user  configuration  file  rather than the default of ~/.manpath.

to the  C function setlocale(3) which interrogates various environ‐ ment variables, possibly including $LC_MESSAGES and  $LANG.   To temporarily  override  the  determined value, use this option to supply a locale string directly to whatis.  Note  that  it  will not  take  effect  until  the  search for pages actually begins. Output such as the help message will always be displayed in  the initially determined locale.
Normally, output will be  truncated  to  the terminal width to avoid ugly results from poorly-written NAME sections.

an alternate set of colon-delimited manual page hierar‐ chies to search.  By default, whatis uses the $MANPATH  environ‐ ment  variable,  unless  it  is empty or unset, in which case it will determine an appropriate manpath based on your $PATH  envi‐ ronment  variable.   This option overrides the contents of $MAN‐ PATH.
each name as a regular expression.  If a name matches any part of a page name, a match  will  be  made.   This  option causes  whatis  to be somewhat slower due to the nature of data‐ base searches.

list  is  a  colon-  or comma-separated list of sections.  If an entry in list is a sim‐ ple  section,  for  example  "3", then the displayed list of de‐ scriptions will include pages in sections  "3",  "3perl",  "3x", and so on; while if an entry in list has an extension, for exam‐ ple "3perl", then the list will only include pages in that exact part of the manual section.
this  system  has  access to other operating systems' manual page names, they can be accessed using this option.   To  search NewOS's manual page names, use the option -m NewOS.
shell  style  wild‐ cards.   For a match to be made, an expanded name must match the entire page name.  This option  causes  whatis  to  be  somewhat slower due to the nature of database searches.
